payload.name: prototype-similarity-based
payload.core: Categorize items by measured similarity to stored prototypes/exemplars rather than necessary-and-sufficient definitions. Produces graded membership where typicality = proximity to prototype in feature space. Central insight: categories have internal structure with central members and fuzzy boundaries.

out.d: numeric similarity values for each item-prototype pair
documented exemplars defining each category center
items near category edges with multi-category scores
pairwise distances between items and all prototypes

proc: define feature space: select attributes relevant to categorization task
curate prototypes: identify 1-3 central exemplars per category (most typical, least controversial)
specify similarity metric: choose distance function matching domain semantics (cosine, Euclidean, weighted features)
compute similarity: measure distance from item to each prototype in feature space
assign graded membership: typicality = inverse distance or similarity score
resolve multi-category: item may belong partially to multiple categories; report all scores above threshold
flag boundary cases: items equidistant from multiple prototypes require human review or multi-label
validate: spot-check assignments against domain expert intuitions
check: prototypes selected by domain experts, not arbitrary examples?
prototype set covers category diversity (not just one subtype)?
similarity metric validated against human similarity judgments?
feature weights reflect domain importance, not data prevalence?
boundary items explicitly flagged rather than force-assigned?
bias audit: prototypes not skewed toward majority subgroup?

diff.vs_fuzzy_logic_25: prototype uses distance to exemplars; fuzzy uses membership functions without stored examples. Fuzzy asks 'how much does X satisfy predicate P?' Prototype asks 'how similar is X to exemplar E?'
diff.vs_case_based_15: prototype classifies only; case-based retrieves cases then adapts solutions. Prototype stops at 'this ticket is type-A'; case-based continues to 'here is how we solved similar type-A tickets'
diff.vs_analogical_14: prototype measures similarity for category membership; analogical transfers relational structure for inference. Prototype: 'robin is bird-like'. Analogical: 'heart is pump-like, therefore has valves'
diff.vs_rough_set_27: prototype uses distance in feature space; rough-set uses equivalence classes from indiscernibility. Prototype yields continuous typicality; rough-set yields lower/upper bounds
diff.vs_default_typicality_31: prototype computes similarity scores; default/typicality uses logical defaults that can be overridden. Prototype: 'penguin is 0.4 typical bird'. Default: 'birds fly unless exception'

confusions.example: '0.8 typicality' interpreted as '80% chance of membership'
confusions.fix: typicality is similarity to central example, not likelihood of category membership

confusions.error: using prototype reasoning when definitions exist
confusions.example: classifying 'is this a prime number?' by similarity to example primes
confusions.fix: use deductive reasoning for well-defined categories; prototype is for family-resemblance concepts

fail.desc: hidden bias in prototypes propagates to all classifications; category drift over time; minority subtypes systematically misclassified
signals: prototypes selected by convenience rather than domain expertise
single prototype per category ignores within-category diversity
similarity metric not validated against human judgments
boundary items force-assigned without flagging uncertainty
no periodic review of prototype relevance as domain evolves
mitigations: audit prototype selection: document why each exemplar chosen; require domain expert sign-off
use multiple prototypes per category: minimum 2-3 exemplars covering major subtypes
validate similarity metric: test against human similarity ratings on held-out pairs
flag boundary items: items within 10% of decision boundary require human review
scheduled prototype review: quarterly assessment of prototype relevance and drift
stratified testing: verify classification accuracy across demographic/domain subgroups

use: UX taxonomies where categories lack crisp definitions
support ticket routing by similarity to exemplar tickets
content moderation with graded severity scores
search result clustering around topic exemplars

ex.scenario: categorizing support tickets by similarity to prototype ticket types
steps: define prototypes: select 3 exemplar tickets per category (billing, technical, account) from resolved high-confidence cases
choose metric: TF-IDF cosine similarity on ticket text plus weighted categorical features (product, urgency)
compute: new ticket similarity = [0.82 billing, 0.31 technical, 0.15 account]
assign: primary=billing (0.82), flag if second-highest > 0.6 for multi-category review
validate: sample 50 assignments weekly, compare to human labels, adjust prototypes if drift detected
ex.insight: ticket is 'billing-like' with degree 0.82, not '82% probability of being billing'
